vi_translation: Mr. Bennet's personality was a blend of cunning, sarcastic humor, reserve, and unpredictability, so much so that even after decades of living together, his wife still couldn't understand him. en: â€œPride,â€ observed Mary, who piqued herself upon the solidity of her reflections, â€œis a very common failing, I believe. By all that I have ever read, I am convinced that it is very common indeed; that human nature is particularly prone to it, and that there are very few of us who do not cherish a feeling of self-complacency on the score of some quality or other, real or imaginary. Vanity and pride are different things, though the words are often used synonymously. A person may be proud without being vain. Pride relates more to our opinion of ourselves; vanity to what we would have others think of us.â€

vi_translation: Mary was still resentful of her sister's steadfast opinion: - I believe that pride is a very common flaw. From what I have read, I believe that this is very prevalent, human nature tends to lean towards this defect. Among us, very few people do not have a self-satisfied thought in one way or another, whether real or imagined. Vanity and pride are two different things, although people often consider them synonymous. A person can feel pride without being vain. Pride is when we have an opinion of ourselves, vanity is when we want others to think of us in a certain way.

en: â€œThere was just such an informality in the terms of the bequest as to give me no hope from law. A man of honour could not have doubted the intention, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt itâ€”or to treat it as a merely conditional recommendation, and to assert that I had forfeited all claim to it by extravagance, imprudence, in short, anything or nothing. Certain it is that the living became vacant two years ago, exactly as I was of an age to hold it, and that it was given to another man; and no less certain is it, that I cannot accuse myself of having really done anything to deserve to lose it. I have a warm unguarded temper, and I may perhaps have sometimes spoken my opinion of him, and to him, too freely. I can recall nothing worse. But the fact is, that we are very different sort of men, and that he hates me.â€

es_translation: â€“â€“There was so much informality in the terms of the legacy that the law would not have given me any hope. A man of honor would not have doubted the intention of those terms; but Darcy preferred to doubt it or take it as a merely conditional recommendation and asserted that I had lost all my rights due to my extravagance and imprudence; in short, either for one reason or another, the fact is that the rectory became vacant two years ago, just when I was old enough to occupy it, and it was given to someone else; and it is no less true that I cannot blame myself for having done anything to deserve losing it. I have a fiery temperament, I am indiscreet, and perhaps I have expressed my opinion about Darcy a few times, and even to him, with excessive frankness. I do not remember anything else I could be accused of. But the fact is that we are very different and that he hates me.

tr_translation: "There was something unofficial in the conditions of the will, it didn't give me a chance in the eyes of the law. An honorable man couldn't doubt the intention here, but Mr. Darcy chose to doubt â€“ or thought it was a conditional recommendation and claimed that I had renounced all my rights, saying I was extravagant, saying I was imprudent â€“ whatever came to his mind. That church also became vacant two years ago, just when I was of age to take over, and it was given to someone else, that's certain; but it's also certain that I can't accuse myself of having done anything to deserve losing that church. I have a warm, unprotected nature; I may have sometimes spoken freely about my opinions of him, I may have even said something to him. I can't think of anything worse. But the truth is, we are very different kinds of people and he hates me."

vi_translation: - There is one clause in the will that leaves me with no hope from the law. A man of honor cannot doubt the intention, but Mr. Darcy deliberately doubts, or considers it merely a conditional proposal, and asserts that I have forfeited all rights in it through reckless extravagance, something like that. What is certain is that the income was gone two years ago, at the time I came of age to benefit from it. This amount was assigned to someone else. It is also certain that I cannot convict myself of having actually done anything to deserve disinheritance. I have a hot temper, cannot restrain myself; perhaps I occasionally said something too loose about him, or to him. I do not remember doing anything worse. But the truth is, we belong to two very different types of people, and he hates me.

As a child, she was affectionate and pleasing, and extremely fond of me; and I have devoted hours and hours to her amusement. But she is nothing to me now. She is a handsome girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and, I understand, highly accomplished. Since her fatherâ€™s death her home has been London, where a lady lives with her, and superintends her education.â€

vi_translation: He shook his head: -I wish I could say she was charming. I feel sad speaking ill of a member of the Darcy family. But she is just like her brother, proud, very proud. When she was a child, she was affectionate and pleasant, and she was very fond of me; I spent a lot of time playing with her. But now, to her, I am nothing. She is a pretty girl, about fifteen or sixteen, and as far as I know, she has quite a few talents. Since her father passed away, she has been living in London, with a lady who stays with her and acts as her governess.

en: â€œProbably not; but Mr. Darcy can please where he chooses. He does not want abilities. He can be a conversible companion if he thinks it worth his while. Among those who are at all his equals in consequence, he is a very different man from what he is to the less prosperous. His pride never deserts him; but with the rich he is liberal-minded, just, sincere, rational, honourable, and, perhaps, agreeable,â€”allowing something for fortune and figure.â€

es_translation: â€“â€“Probably not; but Mr. Darcy knows how to please when he feels like it. He doesn't need to make an effort. Pride never leaves him, but with the wealthy, he adopts a liberal mindset; he is fair, sincere, reasonable, honorable, and perhaps even pleasant, partly due to his fortune and good looks.

vi_translation: - Mom, please don't go. I beg you, don't go. Please forgive me, Mr. Collins. He has nothing to say to me that others don't need to hear. I'm about to leave as well.

en: â€œBelieve me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, so far from doing you any disservice, rather adds to your other perfections. You would have been less amiable in my eyes had there not been this little unwillingness; but allow me to assure you that I have your respected motherâ€™s permission for this address. You can hardly doubt the purport of my discourse, however your natural delicacy may lead you to dissemble; my attentions have been too marked to be mistaken. Almost as soon as I entered the house I singled you out as the companion of my future life. But before I am run away with by my feelings on this subject, perhaps it will be advisable for me to state my reasons for marryingâ€”and, moreover, for coming into Hertfordshire with the design of selecting a wife, as I certainly did.â€
es: â€“â€“CrÃ©ame, mi querida seÃ±orita Elizabeth, que su modestia, en vez de perjudicarla, viene a sumarse a sus otras perfecciones. Ya debe saber cuÃ¡l es el objeto de mi discurso; aunque su natural delicadeza la lleve a disimularlo; mis intenciones han quedado demasiado patentes para que puedan inducir a error. Casi en el momento en que pisÃ© esta casa, la elegÃ­ a usted para futura compaÃ±era de mi vida. Pero antes de expresar mis sentimientos, quizÃ¡ sea aconsejable que exponga las razones que tengo para casarme, y por quÃ© vine a Hertfordshire con la idea de buscar una esposa precisamente aquÃ­.
es_translation: â€“â€“Believe me, my dear Miss Elizabeth, that your modesty, instead of harming you, adds to your other perfections. I would have found you less adorable if you had not shown that little resistance. But allow me to assure you that your mother has given me permission for this interview. You must already know the object of my discourse; although your natural delicacy leads you to conceal it; my intentions have been too evident to be mistaken. Almost from the moment I set foot in this house, I chose you as the future companion of my life. But before expressing my feelings, it might be advisable to explain the reasons I have for marrying, and why I came to Hertfordshire with the idea of finding a wife precisely here.

tr_translation: "Believe me, dear Elizabeth, your modesty, far from doing you any disservice, adds perfection to your perfection. If it were not for this little unwillingness, you would appear less admirable in my eyes; but allow me to assure you, I have obtained your venerable mother's permission for this conversation. You cannot doubt the purpose of my words, but your natural delicacy may cause your mind to be confused; the interest I have shown was too evident to be disregarded. As soon as I entered the house, I chose you as my future life partner. But before my feelings on the subject take over my senses, it might be appropriate to state my reasons for marriage â€“ indeed, the reason for my coming to Hertfordshire with the intention of choosing a wife."

vi_translation: - Dear Miss Elizabeth, please believe that your humility so far has not harmed you at all; on the contrary, it complements your perfections. In my eyes, you might be less charming if you had not shown such modesty, but I assure you that your esteemed mother has permitted me to converse with you in this manner. Surely you do not doubt my intentions, although your innate delicacy might make you ignore them; my feelings are too clear to be mistaken. From the moment I entered this house, I chose you as my companion for my future life. But before I stray too far from the subject due to my emotions in this matter, perhaps I should state the reasons for marriage when I came to Hertfordshire with the intention of finding a wife, for indeed I had this intention.

en: â€œI am not now to learn,â€ replied Mr. Collins, with a formal wave of the hand, â€œthat it is usual with young ladies to reject the addresses of the man whom they secretly mean to accept, when he first applies for their favour; and that sometimes the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time. I am, therefore, by no means discouraged by what you have just said, and shall hope to lead you to the altar ere long.â€
es: â€“â€“SÃ© de sobra â€“â€“replicÃ³ Collins con un grave gesto de su manoâ€“â€“ que entre las jÃ³venes es muy corriente rechazar las proposiciones del hombre a quien, en el fondo, piensan aceptar, cuando pide su preferencia por primera vez, y que la negativa se repite una segunda o incluso una tercera vez. Por esto no me descorazona en absoluto lo que acaba de decirme, y espero llevarla al altar dentro de poco.
es_translation: â€“â€“I know full well â€“â€“replied Collins with a grave gesture of his handâ€“â€“ that among young women it is very common to reject the proposals of the man whom, deep down, they intend to accept, when he asks for their preference for the first time, and that the refusal is repeated a second or even a third time. For this reason, what you have just told me does not discourage me at all, and I hope to lead you to the altar soon.

tr_translation: "I do not wish to learn immediately," Mr. Collins replied, waving his hand formally, "it is normal for young ladies to reject the proposal of a man they intend to accept at first; sometimes a second, or even a third refusal may occur. Therefore, your words never discourage me; I hope to soon lead you to the altar.""

vi_translation: Mr. Collins replied, with a ceremonious wave of his hand: - Until now, I have always known that when a young man proposes for the first time, young women often refuse while inwardly they are inclined to accept, and that they may refuse two or even three times. Therefore, I was not discouraged by what you just said, but rather hopeful that I would soon be married to you.

en: â€œYou must give me leave to flatter myself, my dear cousin, that your refusal of my addresses are merely words of course. My reasons for believing it are briefly these:â€”It does not appear to me that my hand is unworthy your acceptance, or that the establishment I can offer would be any other than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connections with the family of De Bourgh, and my relationship to your own, are circumstances highly in my favour; and you should take it into further consideration that, in spite of your manifold attractions, it is by no means certain that another offer of marriage may ever be made you. Your portion is unhappily so small, that it will in all likelihood undo the effects of your loveliness and amiable qualifications. As I must, therefore, conclude that you are not serious in your rejection of me, I shall choose to attribute it to your wish of increasing my love by suspense, according to the usual practice of elegant females.â€
es: â€“â€“Debe dejar que presuma, mi querida prima, que su rechazÃ³ ha sido sÃ³lo de boquilla. Las razones que tengo para creerlo, son las siguientes: no creo que mi mano no merezca ser aceptada por usted ni que la posiciÃ³n que le ofrezco deje de ser altamente apetecible. Mi situaciÃ³n en la vida, mi relaciÃ³n con la familia de Bourgh y mi parentesco con usted son circunstancias importantes en mi favor. Considere, ademÃ¡s, que a pesar de sus muchos atractivos, no es seguro que reciba otra proposiciÃ³n de matrimonio. Su fortuna es tan escasa que anularÃ¡, por desgracia, los efectos de su belleza y buenas cualidades. AsÃ­ pues, como no puedo deducir de todo esto que haya procedido sinceramente al rechazarme, optarÃ© por atribuirlo a su deseo de acrecentar mi amor con el suspense, de acuerdo con la prÃ¡ctica acostumbrada en las mujeres elegantes.
es_translation: â€“â€“You must let me presume, my dear cousin, that your rejection has been merely verbal. The reasons I have for believing this are as follows: I do not believe that my hand is unworthy of being accepted by you, nor that the position I offer is anything less than highly desirable. My situation in life, my connection with the Bourgh family, and my kinship with you are important circumstances in my favor. Consider, moreover, that despite your many attractions, it is not certain that you will receive another marriage proposal. Your fortune is so meager that it will unfortunately nullify the effects of your beauty and good qualities. Therefore, as I cannot deduce from all this that you have sincerely rejected me, I will choose to attribute it to your desire to increase my love with suspense, in accordance with the customary practice among elegant women.

tr_translation: "Allow me to give myself some credit, dear cousin; your refusal of my offer is merely in words. Here are my reasons for believing so: â€“It does not seem to me that I am unworthy of you, and the life I offer is quite attractive. My position in life, my connections with the De Bourgh family, our kinship, all these are in my favor; if you think more thoroughly, despite your many charms, it appears you have not received any other marriage proposals so far. Unfortunately, your income is so small that it surely diminishes the effect of your beauty and charming qualities. Therefore, I conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me; as a reason for your refusal, I see that, as is customary for polite ladies, you wish to increase my love by making me wait."

vi_translation: - My dear, you must allow me to feel gratified that your refusal is merely a matter of course. The reasons for my belief are quite simple. There seems to be no indication that I am unworthy of your acceptance, or that my status is insufficient. My circumstances, my connections with the De Bourgh family, and my relationship with your family are all highly advantageous for me; and you should also consider that although you have many charms, it is not certain that you will receive another proposal. Unfortunately, your dowry is too small for your beauty and other amiable qualities to have much effect. Since I must conclude that you are not serious in rejecting me, I can only believe that you wish for my love to grow deeper in suspense, as is often the way with elegant women.

en: â€œI found,â€ said he, â€œas the time drew near, that I had better not meet Mr. Darcy;â€”that to be in the same room, the same party with him for so many hours together, might be more than I could bear, and that scenes might arise unpleasant to more than myself.â€

es_translation: â€“â€“As the moment approached â€“â€“he saidâ€“â€“ it seemed to me that it would be better not to meet Darcy, for being together in a room for so many hours would have been beyond my strength and the situation could have become unpleasant, moreover, for other people.

tr_translation: "As the time approached," she said, "I felt it would be better not to encounter Mr. Darcy; â€“being in the same room, in the same company with him for so many hours could be more than I could bear, scenes that could disturb others more than myself might occur."

vi_translation: - When that day approached, I thought that I should not meet Mr. Darcy, that being present in the same room, at the same gathering for many hours with him was something I could not endure, while others might also be affected by the discomfort.

en: â€œâ€˜When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the business which took him to London might be concluded in three or four days; but as we are certain it cannot be so, and at the same time convinced that when Charles gets to town he will be in no hurry to leave it again, we have determined on following him thither, that he may not be obliged to spend his vacant hours in a comfortless hotel. Many of my acquaintance are already there for the winter: I wish I could hear that you, my dearest friend, had any intention of making one in the crowd, but of that I despair. I sincerely hope your Christmas in Hertfordshire may abound in the gaieties which that season generally brings, and that your beaux will be so numerous as to prevent your feeling the loss of the three of whom we shall deprive you.â€™
es: Te lo leerÃ©: Â«Cuando mi hermano nos dejÃ³ ayer, se imaginaba que los asuntos que le llamaban a Londres podrÃ­an despacharse en tres o cuatro dÃ­as; pero como sabemos que no serÃ¡ asÃ­ y convencidas, al mismo tiempo, de que cuando Charles va a la capital no tiene prisa por volver, hemos determinado irnos con Ã©l para que no tenga que pasarse las horas que le quedan libres en un hotel, sin ninguna comodidad. Muchas de nuestras relaciones estÃ¡n ya allÃ­ para pasar el invierno; me gustarÃ­a saber si usted, queridÃ­sima amiga, piensa hacer lo mismo; pero no lo creo posible. Deseo sinceramente que las navidades en Hertfordshire sean prÃ³digas en las alegrÃ­as propias de esas festividades, y que sus galanes sean tan numerosos que les impidan sentir la pÃ©rdida de los tres caballeros que les arrebatamos.Â»
es_translation: I will read it to you: Â«When my brother left us yesterday, he imagined that the matters calling him to London could be handled in three or four days; but as we know that this will not be the case and convinced, at the same time, that when Charles goes to the capital he is in no hurry to return, we have decided to go with him so that he does not have to spend his free hours in a hotel, without any comfort. Many of our acquaintances are already there to spend the winter; I would like to know if you, dearest friend, plan to do the same; but I don't think it possible. I sincerely wish that Christmas in Hertfordshire is bountiful in the joys typical of these festivities, and that your suitors are so numerous that they prevent you from feeling the loss of the three gentlemen we are taking away from you.Â»

tr_translation: " â€˜My brother, when leaving us yesterday, thought that the business requiring him to go to London could be handled within three or four days; but now that we know this is not possible, and also believing that Charles will not return once he gets to the city, we decided to follow him so that he wouldn't have to spend his idle hours in an uncomfortable hotel. Most of my acquaintances have already come there for the winter; I wish you too, my dear friend, would consider joining us â€“ but I am not hopeful about this. With all my heart, I wish that Christmas brings joy to Hertfordshire and to you as it always does, and that your admirers prevent you from feeling the loss of the three friends we have deprived you of.' "

vi_translation: "When my brother left yesterday, he thought that the job in London might be finished in three or four days, but we couldn't believe it. At the same time, we thought that once Charles was in the city, he wouldn't be in a hurry to leave, so we decided to follow him, so he wouldn't be alone in the uncomfortable hotel room." "Many of my acquaintances have gone there for the winter; I wish you, my closest friend, could join the crowd, but I'm not sure." "I sincerely wish you a Merry Christmas in Herfordshire, and you will have many suitors to help you forget the three of us."

en: â€œYou are too sensible a girl, Lizzy, to fall in love merely because you are warned against it; and, therefore, I am not afraid of speaking openly. Seriously, I would have you be on your guard. Do not involve yourself, or endeavour to involve him, in an affection which the want of fortune would make so very imprudent. I have nothing to say against him: he is a most interesting young man; and if he had the fortune he ought to have, I should think you could not do better. But as it isâ€”you must not let your fancy run away with you. You have sense, and we all expect you to use it. Your father would depend on your resolution and good conduct, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father.â€

Tienes mucho sentido, y todos esperamos que lo uses. Tu padre confÃ­a en tu firmeza y en tu buena conducta. No vayas a defraudarle.
es_translation: â€“â€“You are a girl too sensible, Lizzy, to fall in love just because you were warned not to; and for that reason, I dare to speak to you openly. Seriously, be careful. Do not commit yourself, nor let him get involved in an affection that the lack of fortune can turn into imprudence. I have nothing to say against him; he is a very interesting young man, and if he had the position he should have, he would seem unbeatable to me. But as things stand, you cannot blind yourself. You have a lot of sense, and we all expect you to use it. Your father trusts in your firmness and good conduct. Do not disappoint him.

BabanÄ± hayal kÄ±rÄ±klÄ±ÄŸÄ±na uÄŸratmamalÄ±sÄ±n.
tr_translation: "You are a very sensible girl, Lizzy, you won't fall in love with anyone just because you were warned; so I am not afraid to speak openly with you. Seriously, I advise you to protect yourself. Do not enter into or try to force a relationship that would be impossible due to lack of money. I have nothing against him; he is a very interesting young man; if he had the fortune he deserved, I would say you couldn't do better. But in his current state, you must not let yourself get carried away by dreams. You have common sense, and we all want to see you use it. Your father trusts your decisions and actions, I am sure. You must not disappoint your father."

vi_translation: - Lizzy, you are mature enough not to fall in love just because you are warned against it. Therefore, I will not hesitate to speak frankly. I need to caution you, and I am serious about this. You should not get entangled with him in a relationship where material desires might make love reckless. I have nothing against him; he is someone worthy of our attention; and if he had the wealth he should have inherited, I could say there would be nothing better for you. You are sensible, and everyone expects you to use your sense. I believe your father will rely on your steadfastness and virtue. You should not disappoint your father.

en: â€œI do not mean to say that a woman may not be settled too near her family. The far and the near must be relative, and depend on many varying circumstances. vi_translation: Elizabeth shouted loudly: - And you caused it. You have driven him into his current state of misery, misery in a relative sense. You have taken hold of all the rights that you should have known were arranged for him. You have taken away the best years of his life, the independent life that he should have enjoyed. You did all these things! And on top of that, you scorn and mock when people mention his misfortunes.

en: â€œAnd this,â€ cried Darcy, as he walked with quick steps across the room, â€œis your opinion of me! This is the estimation in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it so fully. My faults, according to this calculation, are heavy indeed! But, perhaps,â€ added he, stopping in his walk, and turning towards her, â€œthese offences might have been overlooked, had not your pride been hurt by my honest confession of the scruples that had long prevented my forming any serious design. These bitter accusations might have been suppressed, had I, with greater policy, concealed my struggles, and flattered you into the belief of my being impelled by unqualified, unalloyed inclination; by reason, by reflection, by everything. But disguise of every sort is my abhorrence. Nor am I ashamed of the feelings I related. They were natural and just. Could you expect me to rejoice in the inferiority of your connections?â€”to congratulate myself on the hope of relations whose condition in life is so decidedly beneath my own?â€

es_translation: â€“â€“And that is â€“â€“ shouted Darcy as he paced the room like a whirlwind â€“â€“ the opinion you have of me! This is the esteem in which you hold me! I thank you for explaining it to me so openly. My faults, according to your calculation, are truly enormous. But perhaps â€“â€“he added, stopping and turning towards herâ€“â€“ these offenses would have been overlooked if I had not wounded your pride with my honest confession of the reservations that for a long time prevented me from making a decision. I would have spared myself these bitter accusations if I had been more skillful and had hidden my struggle, flattering you by making you believe that I had taken this step driven by reason, by reflection, by an unconditional and pure inclination, by whatever. But I abhor all kinds of deceit and I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed, they were natural and just. How could you suppose that I would be pleased by the inferiority of your family and that I would congratulate myself on the prospect of having relatives whose condition is so far below mine?

tr_translation: "So, this is it," cried Darcy as he paced the room briskly, "so this is what you think of me! So this is how you see me! Thank you for explaining it so thoroughly. According to this account, my faults are indeed great! Perhaps," he added, turning towards her, "these insults could have been overlooked, but your pride was wounded because I honestly confessed the concerns that have long prevented me from making a serious attempt. If I had concealed my struggle with a finer strategy, flattering your pride with reason, logic, and everything, making you believe I was a captive of an indescribable, pure passion, these bitter accusations might have been dismissed. But I despise every kind of falsehood. Moreover, I am not ashamed of the feelings I have expressed. Because they are natural and justified feelings. Can you expect me to take pleasure in the low status of your relatives? Should I congratulate myself for having kin whose positions in life are so far below mine?"

vi_translation: Darcy exclaimed, as he paced quickly around the room: - So that's what you think of me! That's how you judge me! Thank you for explaining it thoroughly. According to that reasoning, my faults are indeed severe! He stopped walking and turned to look at her: - But perhaps these faults would have been overlooked if her pride had not been hurt by my sincere confession of the long-standing hesitations that had prevented me from having serious intentions. These bitter accusations would have been restrained if I had tried harder to conceal the struggles within my soul, to make her complacently believe that I had been driven by unburdened, pure emotions; by reason, by recollection, by everything. But I hate concealing anything. And I am not ashamed of the feelings I have confessed. These feelings are natural and legitimate. Could she expect me to be happy in a lower position in relation to her? To expect me to congratulate myself on the hopes of relatives who are entirely lower in status than I am?

es_translation: But when she came to the part concerning Wickham, she read with greater attention. Faced with that account of events which, if true, would destroy all her good opinion of the young man, and which bore an alarming similarity to what Wickham himself had told her, her feelings became even more distressing and harder to define; confusion, suspicion, and even horror overwhelmed her. She wanted to deny it all and repeatedly exclaimed: "That must be false, it can't be true! It must be the greatest of lies!" She finished reading the letter, and without having taken in the last one or two pages, she quickly put it away, complaining to herself that she would not look at it again, that she did not want to know anything about it.

en: With this answer Elizabeth was forced to be content; but her own opinion continued the same, and she left him disappointed and sorry. It was not in her nature, however, to increase her vexations by dwelling on them. She was confident of having performed her duty; and to fret over unavoidable evils, or augment them by anxiety, was no part of her disposition.

en: Elizabeth, however, had never been blind to the impropriety of her fatherâ€™s behaviour as a husband. She had always seen it with pain; but respecting his abilities, and grateful for his affectionate treatment of herself, she endeavoured to forget what she could not overlook, and to banish from her thoughts that continual breach of conjugal obligation and decorum which, in exposing his wife to the contempt of her own children, was so highly reprehensible. But she had never felt so strongly as now the disadvantages which must attend the children of so unsuitable a marriage, nor ever been so fully aware of the evils arising from so ill-judged a direction of talentsâ€”talents which, rightly used, might at least have preserved the respectability of his daughters, even if incapable of enlarging the mind of his wife.
es: Elizabeth, no obstante, nunca habÃ­a dejado de reconocer la inconveniencia de la conducta de su padre como marido. Siempre la habÃ­a observado con pena, pero respetaba su talento y le agradecÃ­a su cariÃ±o, por lo que procuraba olvidar lo que no podÃ­a ignorar y apartar de sus pensamientos su continua infracciÃ³n de los deberes conyugales y del decoro que, por el hecho de exponer a su esposa al desprecio de sus propias hijas, era tan sumamente reprochable. Pero nunca habÃ­a sentido como entonces los males que puede causar a los hijos un matrimonio mal avenido, ni nunca se habÃ­a dado cuenta tan claramente de los peligros que entraÃ±a la direcciÃ³n errada del talento, talento que, bien empleado, aunque no hubiese basta-do para aumentar la inteligencia de su mujer, habrÃ­a podido, al menos, conservar la respetabilidad de las hijas.
es_translation: Elizabeth, nevertheless, had never ceased to recognize the impropriety of her father's conduct as a husband. She had always observed it with sorrow, but she respected his talent and was grateful for his affection, so she tried to forget what she could not ignore and to put out of her mind his continuous breach of marital duties and the decorum that, by exposing his wife to the contempt of her own daughters, was so exceedingly reprehensible. But she had never felt as she did then the harm that a discordant marriage can cause to the children, nor had she ever so clearly realized the dangers inherent in the misdirection of talent, talent that, if well employed, although it might not have been enough to enhance his wife's intelligence, could at least have preserved the respectability of the daughters.

tr_translation: However, Elizabeth had never been blind to her father's inappropriate behavior as a husband. She had always watched these with pain; but because she respected her father's abilities and was grateful for the love he showed her, she tried not to think about the extremely unpleasant act of constantly violating the duties and decorum of marriage, such as belittling his wife at every opportunity in front of their children. But never had she felt so strongly the troubles that children of such an incompatible marriage had to endure; never had she understood so well the harm caused by talents directed at the wrong targets â€“ talents that, if used correctly, could at least have preserved her daughters' dignity, even if they failed to improve her wife's mind.

vi_translation: However, Elizabeth had never ignored his improper behaviors as a husband. She was always distressed to see him like that, but out of respect for his abilities and happiness at being cherished by him, she tried to forget what she could not overlook and pushed out of her mind the sad actions when he showed irresponsibility or lacked the spirit of marital decorum by exposing his wife to the contempt of their children. But she had never deeply felt the disadvantages for the daughters in such a discordant marriage, nor had she ever recognized the harms of misusing talents â€“ talents that, if properly harnessed, could at least earn the daughters respect from others, if not broaden the mind of their mother.

en: Accordingly, when she retired at night, she asked the chambermaid whether Pemberley were not a very fine place, what was the name of its proprietor, and, with no little alarm, whether the family were down for the summer? A most welcome negative followed the last question; and her alarms being now removed, she was at leisure to feel a great deal of curiosity to see the house herself; and when the subject was revived the next morning, and she was again applied to, could readily answer, and with a proper air of indifference, that she had not really any dislike to the scheme.
